entry.et: Middle English, from Old English wīd; akin to Old High German wīt wide

def.dt: :having great extent :vast a wide area
:extending over a vast area :extensive a wide reputation
:extending throughout a specified area or scope usually used in combination nationwide industry-wide
:comprehensive inclusive a wide assortment
:having a specified extension from side to side 3 feet wide
:having much extent between the sides :broad a wide doorway
:fully opened wide-eyed
:lax 4
:extending or fluctuating considerably between limits a wide variation
:straying or deviating from something specified used with of the accusation was wide of the truth
:relatively rich in carbohydrate as compared with protein
:over a great distance or extent :widely searched far and wide
:over a specified distance, area, or extent usually used in combination expanded the business country-wide
:so as to leave much space or distance between placed wide apart
:so as to pass at or clear by a considerable distance ran wide around left end
:to the fullest extent :completely fully wide open
:having or covering an angle of view wider than the ordinary used especially of lenses of shorter than normal focal length
:having, involving the use of, or relating to a wide-angle lens a wide–angle shot
:a network of computers (as the Internet) in a large area (as a country or the globe) for sharing resources or exchanging data
:fully awake
:alertly watchful especially for advantages or opportunities
:a large jet aircraft characterized by a wide cabin
:having or marked by unsophisticated or uncritical acceptance or admiration :naive wide–eyed innocence
:having the eyes wide open especially with wonder or astonishment
:having virtually no limits or restrictions a wide–open town
:extensive in scope :comprehensive wide–ranging interests
:a football receiver who normally lines up several yards to the side of the offensive formation
